memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr a, [In] ref int bins, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: paa

briefdescription.para:
Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) approximates a time series $X$ of length $n$ into vector $\bar{X}=(\bar{x}_{1},â€¦,\bar{x}_{M})$ of any arbitrary length $M \leq n$ where each of $\bar{x_{i}}$ is calculated as follows: \[ \bar{x}_{i} = \frac{M}{n} \sum_{j=n/M(i-1)+1}^{(n/M)i} x_{j}. \] Which simply means that in order to reduce the dimensionality from $n$ to $M$, we first divide the original time series into $M$ equally sized frames and secondly compute the mean values for each frame. The sequence assembled from the mean values is the PAA approximation (i.e., transform) of the original time series. /summary>
a
Set of points.
bins
Sets the total number of divisions.
result
An array of points with the reduced dimensionality.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr a, [In] ref int number_ips, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: pip

briefdescription.para: Calculates the number of Perceptually Important Points (PIP) in the time series.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Fu TC, Chung FL, Luk R, and Ng CM. Representing financial time series based on data point importance. Engineering Applications of Artificial Intelligence, 21(2):277-300, 2008. /summary>
a
Expects an input array whose dimension zero is the length of the time series.
number_ips
The number of points to be returned.
result
Array with the most Perceptually Important number_ips.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr ts, [In] ref float max_error, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: pla_bottom_up

briefdescription.para: Applies the Piecewise Linear Approximation (PLA BottomUP) to the time series.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Zhu Y, Wu D, Li Sh (2007). A Piecewise Linear Representation Method of Time Series Based on Feature Points. Knowledge-Based Intelligent Information and Engineering Systems 4693:1066-1072. /summary>
ts
Expects a khiva_array containing the set of points to be reduced. The first component of the points in the first column and the second component of the points in the second column.
max_error
The maximum approximation error allowed.
result
The reduced number of points.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr ts, [In] ref float max_error, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: pla_sliding_window

briefdescription.para: Applies the Piecewise Linear Approximation (PLA Sliding Window) to the time series.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Zhu Y, Wu D, Li Sh (2007). A Piecewise Linear Representation Method of Time Series Based on Feature Points. Knowledge-Based Intelligent Information and Engineering Systems 4693:1066-1072. /summary>
ts
Expects a khiva_array containing the set of points to be reduced. The first component of the points in the first column and the second component of the points in the second column.
max_error
The maximum approximation error allowed.
result
The reduced number of points.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr points, [In] ref double epsilon, [Out] out IntPtr res_points)
memberdef.name: ramer_douglas_peucker

briefdescription.para: The Ramerâ€“Douglasâ€“Peucker algorithm (RDP) is an algorithm for reducing the number of points in a curve that is approximated by a series of points. It reduces a set of points depending on the perpendicular distance of the points and epsilon, the greater epsilon, more points are deleted.

detaileddescription.para: [1] Urs Ramer, "An iterative procedure for the polygonal approximation of plane curves", Computer Graphics and Image Processing, 1(3), 244â€“256 (1972) doi:10.1016/S0146-664X(72)80017-0.

[2] David Douglas & Thomas Peucker, "Algorithms for the reduction of the number of points required to represent a digitized line or its caricature", The Canadian Cartographer 10(2), 112â€“122 (1973) doi:10.3138/FM57-6770-U75U-7727 /summary>
points
Array with the x-coordinates and y-coordinates of the input points (x in column 0 and y in column 1).
epsilon
It acts as the threshold value to decide which points should be considered meaningful or not.
res_points
Array with the x-coordinates and y-coordinates of the selected points (x in column 0 and y in column 1).

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr a, [In] ref int alphabet_size, [Out] out IntPtr result)
memberdef.name: sax

briefdescription.para: Symbolic Aggregate approXimation (SAX). It transforms a numeric time series into a time series of symbols with the same size. The algorithm was proposed by Lin et al.) and extends the PAA-based approach inheriting the original algorithm simplicity and low computational complexity while providing satisfactory sensitivity and selectivity in range query processing. Moreover, the use of a symbolic representation opened a door to the existing wealth of data-structures and string-manipulation algorithms in computer science such as hashing, regular expression, pattern matching, suffix trees, and grammatical inference.

detaileddescription.para:
[1] Lin, J., Keogh, E., Lonardi, S. & Chiu, B. (2003) A Symbolic Representation of Time Series, with Implications for Streaming Algorithms. In proceedings of the 8th ACM SIGMOD Workshop on Research Issues in Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery. San Diego, CA. June 13. /summary>
a
Array with the input time series.
alphabet_size
Number of element within the alphabet.
result
An array of symbols.

memberdef.argsstring: ([In] ref IntPtr points, [In] ref int num_points, [Out] out IntPtr res_points)
memberdef.name: visvalingam

briefdescription.para: Reduces a set of points by applying the Visvalingam method (minimum triangle area) until the number of points is reduced to numPoints.

detaileddescription.para: [1] M. Visvalingam and J. D. Whyatt, Line generalisation by repeated elimination of points, The Cartographic Journal, 1993.

parameterdescription.para: Array with the x-coordinates and y-coordinates of the input points (x in column 0 and y in column 1).
Sets the number of points returned after the execution of the method.
Array with the x-coordinates and y-coordinates of the selected points (x in column 0 and y in column 1).

briefdescription.para: Khiva Dimensionality class containing several dimensionality reduction methods.
